Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: They notice minor inconsistencies in a building plan that are unlikely to cause immediate issues.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, red pen poised to mark the minor inconsistencies I’d just noticed. They weren’t major—nothing that would cause immediate danger—but as an architect, I knew the rules: every detail mattered, every line had to be perfect. My phone buzzed, and I saw my sibling’s name flash on the screen. I hesitated, remembering the call earlier that day—their voice trembling as they shared the difficult news, the kind that shakes your world and leaves you gasping for air. I knew what was expected of me: to be there, to listen, to offer comfort and support. But the plans in front of me demanded my attention, too. If I let these small errors slide, I’d be betraying my professional standards. If I ignored my sibling, I’d be failing them when they needed me most. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between the weight of family and the responsibility of my work, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in on me.
